blog.name: sketchasoiaf
blog.title: A Sketch of Ice and Fire
blog.description:
My name is Noa and I'm re-reading and drawing each chapter of a Song of Ice and Fire. Updated 3 times a week.

Contact me at noa@null.co.il | Main art tumblr: http://noalp.tumblr.com | My Patreon

View by Character POV: Jon | Tyrion | Daenerys | Ned | Catelyn | Arya | Sansa | Bran | Theon | Davos | Jaime

Books and movies are my obsession.

Food and laughter my god.

summary: Lady Catelyn does return as Lady Stoneheart, but believes that Sansa is part of the betrayal that killed her family. Stoneheart...
body: Lady Catelyn does return as Lady Stoneheart, but believes that Sansa is part of the betrayal that killed her family. Stoneheart tries to get revenge, but the people who love her and are able to protect her keep her from harm’s way.

summary: Arya has really great oak symbolism running through her story: "I look like an oak tree, with all these stupid acorns." "Nice,...
body:
Arya has really great oak symbolism running through her story:

“I look like an oak tree, with all these stupid acorns.”
“Nice, though. A nice oak tree.”

Oak trees represent strength and steadfastness, endurance and long life. I think Arya is going to live long after the War for the Dawn is won. 

“Of all the trees in Britain and Ireland the oak is considered king” and we know what GRRM thinks of kings: “a king protects his people, or he is no king at all.” Arya herself is canonically a princess by the end of AGOT, if we recognize the North’s independence. Like any good leader, Arya desires justice, she’s appalled by the mistreatment of the smallfolk, and she stands up for the downtrodden (women, orphans, anyone who was treated poorly by the people in power). 

“Oak-trees have always been regarded as great protectors and guardians of the virtuous.” I think Arya too is a protector; she defends Mycah. She wants to protect Weasel and Gendry and Hot Pie. 

As Jojen tells us, “There is a power in living wood, a power strong as fire.“

The avenging power of the oak was famous, particularly in Somerset […] A local story  told of Carming family that came to grief because of disregarding the power of Oak: Carmer and his oldest son were greedy and cut down oaks in a nearby coppice, although they had plenty of wood of their own. The story continues:

‘Trees didn’t say nothing - which was bad. If they do talk a bit you do get a warning, but if they’m dead still there’s summat bad a-brewing. And zo t'was. Be danged if gurt oak didn ’t drop a limb on can and timber and farmer and eldest son. Killed they two stark dead outright, but when the youngest came to rescue the dead the tree rustled fit to deafen he. ‘

The youngest son was spared because he was always respectful to trees, being sure to ask the ‘great oak by the gate’ if he might go past when he entered the forest, and after he inherited the farm, ‘trees never followed 'n nor closed about 'n, nor let drop branches.’ [x]

Like the oak in the story, Arya is intent on punishing the greedy, grasping Lannisters who cut down her family. 

Like Arya’s journey, the oak has a duality to it, with “deep roots [that] penetrate as deep into the Underworld as its branches soar to the sky.”  Arya passes through underworlds (the tunnels below the Red Keep, the Brotherhood’s hollow hill, the dungeons of Harrnehal, the levels below the House of Black and White (going deeper like Dante’s levels or circles of hell)) as much as the world above (her bedroom in the Tower of the Hand, the hidden village in the treetops with the Lady of the Leaves, the crumbling towers of Harrenhal, her squirrel-like journeys through the treetops above Lommy’s head). 

(The Aeneid, anyone? Aeneas’s journey into hell to speak with his father? “Could you bring back a man without a head?”) 

Even in the very beginning, in Arya’s first POV, we see Arya looking down on Winterfell’s yard from high above, from the covered bridge; surely GRRM will bring us full circle and return Arya to Winterfell and the world above by the end? 

Arya herself possesses the duality of death and rebirth, with her prayer-like Valar Morghulis / Valar Dohaeris. She is girl and wolf both. She is blind yet she can see. 

“The Sanskrit word, ‘Duir’, gave rise both to the word for oak and the English word ‘door’, which suggests that this tree stands as an opening into greater wisdom, perhaps an entryway into the otherworld itself.” [x]

Is Arya’s journey a journey into wisdom? After all that has happened to her, she has become wise beyond her years, with a keen understanding of others. As for the otherworld … the Others are surely waiting a bit farther down the road of Arya’s journey. A giant wolfpack roams Westeros, led by a direwolf Arya can warg; it’s difficult to imagine that GRRM would hang this chekhov’s gun on the wall and not use it. 

The end of Arya’s story remains known only to GRRM, but I think the oak motif gives us clues. With the dense oak forests that once covered Northern Europe, the oak was considered vital to life. Oak wood was shelter, oak sticks were fuel for fire, oak acorns were food for the cruel winter.

“Oak and iron, guard me well, or else I’m dead, and doomed to hell.” 

The oak was seen as a tree for building … or rebuilding. 

“Winterfell remained. It was not dead, just broken.”

Jon, about Melisandre: she’s essentially living a life! We can’t kill her!

Arya: *fist bumps with gendry*
trail.content:
Jon, about Melisandre: she’s essentially living a life! We can’t kill her!

Arya: not with that attitude, we can’t!

Arya: *fist bumps with gendry*

blog.name: incorrect-got-quotes
blog.title: Dead, almost like my interest in the show
blog.description: I post quotes when I feel like it. Mostly nowadays I don’t.If you want to use one of the quotes as a story or drawing prompt, I'm fine with that, as long as you credit me in your story or art. Also, tag any drawings under #oberyn’s saucy art. Yes, I am in fact Oberyn Martell. For those on mobile, here is my ship list: https://incorrect-got-quotes.tumblr.com/list-of-ships Main: garnetislovegarnetislife. SUBMISSION BOX IS (MOST LIKELY) PERMANENTLY CLOSED!

summary: She had dressed in a low-cut gown of pale yellow silk, startling against the light brown of her skin. Her black hair was bound...
caption: She had dressed in a low-cut gown of pale yellow silk, startling against the light brown of her skin. Her black hair was bound up in a net of spun gold, and a jet-and-gold necklace brushed against the top of her full breasts. TWOW, Mercy I
